title: English woman and her Spanish husband anticipate  tense  Â  atmosphere in their household ahead of Euros final - as their children are forced to pick sides
body_text:
- The Three Lions will take on Spain in Berlin at the Euros 2024 final on Sunday
- READ MORE: Here we go! Pubs get the OK to stay open to 1am for Euros 2024 final as England bid for glory - with fan excitement building already in Germany, UK and even Benidorm
A British-Spanish couple have said they are anticipating a 'tense' but 'fun' atmosphere ahead of the Euro 2024 final tomorrow.
The final between the Three Lions and Spain takes place on Sunday in Berlin and for those in Anglo-Spanish households, excitement seems to be at fever pitch.
Rebecca Garcia, 40, who is English, and her Spanish husband Eugenio, 38, will be watching the match with their daughters Alba, five, and Eva, three.
Mr Garcia, a structural engineer, said he anticipates that there will be mixed feelings in their home in Penge, south London, on Sunday.
'I think I'll be more tense and nervous and [Mrs Garcia] will probably be having some wine,' he said.
Rebecca Garcia (pictured), 40, who is English, and her Spanish husband Eugenio, 38, will be watching the Three Lions take on Spain in the Euros 2024 final with their daughters Alba (pictured), five, and Eva, three
Their score predictions also tell two different stories. Mrs Garcia, who works in construction, believes England will triumph via penalties.
She said: 'I think it will end up going to penalties, which is always a really tough thing to happen to them as people, and the pressure and then I think it will end up with England winning, but on penalties,' Mrs Garcia
Mr Garcia said: 'I think it's going to be 2-0 for Spain,' adding that he expects Lamine Yamal and Nico Williams to score.
The father-of-two, who also supports Liverpool and plays football regularly, said he had not expected his team to reach the final.
'I think on the Spanish side, we've been the surprise of the tournament, I wasn't expecting to be in the final,' he said.
'We managed to play really good football and eliminate big teams like France, Italy, Germany, and we started as the underdog and now we are the favourite in the final.
'On the English side, I think it's been the opposite - we have great players, they're not performing probably as they should be.
It's a string of performances that led Mr Garcia to add: 'England is now the underdog.'
38-year-old father-of-two Eugenio (pictured with Eva) said he anticipates a 'tense' atmosphere in their south London home during the match on Sunday
Eugenio said that his daughter Alba (pictured) appears to have taken a liking to the Spanish team over England
Mrs Garcia said she has been 'rooting' for England the whole way through the tournament and has been hoping they would reach the final.
'It's not every day you get the two sides of your life competing against each other,' she added.
The mother-of-two said her children will most likely 'root for whoever's winning at the time'.
But Mr Garcia quipped: 'I think Alba likes Spain, I think she'll be cheering for Spain, I'll make sure.'
Despite her being only three, Eva may be displaying signs she is a budding footballer as she enjoys running around and kicking footballs.
'It's nice to see them watching the matches and getting behind the excitement of it all,' Mrs Garcia added.
'Alba's got a Spain outfit, so we'll probably put her in that (for the final).' The girls may also have the Spain and England flags painted on their cheeks to pay homage to their mixed heritage.
Adrian Salamon, 42, a magician from York, will support England in the final, unlike his Spanish wife, Azahara Berlango, 42, and their son Tristan, seven, who is 'divided' (pictured from L to R: Adrian, Azahara, and Tristan)
Tristan is seen in their Yorkshire home waving a Spanish flag and donning the country's football shirt
Tristan's parents said that the seven-year-old appears to be rooting for Spain's victory over England's
Adrian Salamon, 42, a magician from York, will watch the final with his Spanish wife, Azahara Berlango, 42, and their son Tristan, seven.
Ms Berlango believes Spain will defeat the Three Lions 2-0, and Mr Salamon predicts the score will be 2-1 to captain Alvaro Morata's team. Tristan is currently 'divided'.
'I think last year he was rooting more for England but this year he seems to be rooting more for Spain,' Ms Berlango said.
The couple watched the Lionesses take on Spain in the Women's World Cup final last August, but 'never' believed they would be seeing England and Spain battle it out once again at a major football tournament.
The father-of-one continued: 'I think because I am very loud when I watch the match, [Tristan] gets more invested in it.' He added: 'It will be tense here, but it will be fun between us.'
The family plan to hold a 'low key' affair and stay at home to watch England face Spain.
'We'll keep it low key. We'll do a little bit of Spanish tapas and English beer,' Ms Berlango said.
Ms Berlango hopes her Spanish flag, which she says will be in 'prime position near her' when the match takes place, will send her team the luck needed to secure victory.
'I got it when Spain played the final of the World Cup 2010 and my flag is always with me. It's my lucky flag,' she said.
She has predicted teenage Spanish right winger Lamine Yamal will score first on Sunday.
'I have a little soft spot for our little Spanish prodigy, Lamine Yamal. I think he'll score first on Sunday,' she said.
Mr Salamon said he asked his wife: 'Wouldn't it be funny?' if England face Spain in the final again.
'We're finding ourselves in this spot again,' Mrs Berlango said.
Mr Salamon joked with his wife: 'You're not going to gloat if we beat you, are you? To which she replied: 'A bit.'
